31. I have already seen how gracefully
the gowns and veils of Nymphs waft like sails,
mostly in one direction, sometimes turning
here and there with the wind; and how
gently rippling are the shifts and veils
of the wanton Bacchantes, running lustily
with torches up and down the steep hills,
and Diana’s maidens hunting in the wilds.
right-middleThe floating veils and linens of the Nymphs.

32. Now, who cannot see the Bull bathing in the Sea,
and the maiden’s gown moving like a sail?
Who would deny our reading
the inventive Exile? How fearful he paints
the young abducted girl! Who could tire of
the veils and ribbons along her Marble throat,
with her golden hair, all floating in the air?
It is right that our Brush listens to such writing.
right-middleThe Example of Europa, described by Ovid.
right-middleThe Painter’s brush listens to the Poet’s pen.

33. I will leave you to take care of
what concerns us further in these matters:
to make other forms of clothing,
various embroideries, cloth of gold,
and also multicolored Damask, with figures.
Pay attention to everything, so as to make no error
When naturally representing a large elaborate fabric;
for that, you must also arrange the colors.

ab.b:
XI. On the Variation or Combining of Colors.
The Eleventh Chapter.

div.ab:
1. You, Scholars of Art which begins in Nature,
will wish to lend your avid ears here.
I shall tell you in what manner
to arrange your colors properly
so as to vary them well, according to correct intention;
which ones (without mixing)
are close to each other and willingly go together
when you start making Draperies
right-middleColors which are pleased to go together.
